009package imagingbook.common.color.gamma;
010
011/**
012 * <p>
013 * Defines the "modified gamma correction" used for converting linear to
014 * non-linear color component values. The mapping function consists of a linear
015 * and non-linear part. In the forward mapping ({@link #applyFwd(double)}), the
016 * linear part covers input values between a = 0,...,a0, while values a =
017 * a0,...,1 are mapped non-linearly. For the inverse mapping
018 * ({@link #applyInv(double)}), the linear part is b = 0,...,b0, the non-linear
019 * part is b = b0,...,1. Theoretically all mapping parameters can be derived
020 * from parameters {@code gamma} and {@code a0} (the linear to non-linear
021 * transition point) only. Note that {@code gamma} specifies the nominal &gamma;
022 * parameter for the <em>forward</em> (i.e., linear to non-linear) mapping, e.g.,
023 * &gamma; = 1/2.4 for sRGB. See Sec. 3.7.6 of [1] for more details.
024 * </p>
025 * <p>
026 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
027 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
028 * </p>
029 * 
030 * @author WB
031 * @version 2022/11/14
032 */
033public class ModifiedGammaMapping implements GammaMapping {
034        
035        /** Gamma mapping function instance for ITU-R BT.709 (see Table 3.1 of [1]). */
036        public static ModifiedGammaMapping ITU709 = new ModifiedGammaMapping(1/2.222, 0.018); //, 4.5, 0.099);
037        
038        /** Gamma mapping function instance for sRGB (see Table 3.1 of [1]). 
039         * Note that we need to specify parameters s and d too to comply 
040         * strictly with the sRGB standard. */
041        public static ModifiedGammaMapping sRGB = new ModifiedGammaMapping(1/2.4, 0.0031308, 12.92, 0.055);
042        
043        private final double gamma;
044        private final double igamma;
045        private final double a0;
046        private final double b0;
047        private final double s;
048        private final double d;
049        
050        /**
051         * Constructor, derives parameters s and d from gamma and a0
052         * (see Eq. 3.35 in [1]).
053         * @param gamma in [0,1], the nominal gamma value for the forward mapping (e.g., gamma = 1/2.4 for sRGB)
054         * @param a0 in [0,1], the linear to non-linear transition point (e.g., a0 = 1/2.4 for sRGB)
055         */
056        public ModifiedGammaMapping(double gamma, double a0) {
057                this(gamma, a0, s(gamma, a0), d(gamma, a0));
058        }
059        
060        /**
061         * Constructor, accepts explicit parameters s and d to allow for
062         * minor inaccuracies in published standards.
063         * 
064         * @param gamma in [0,1], the nominal gamma value for the forward mapping (e.g., gamma = 1/2.4 for sRGB)
065         * @param a0 in [0,1], the linear to non-linear transition point (e.g., a0 = 1/2.4 for sRGB)
066         * @param s &gt; 0, the slope s of the linear section (e.g., s = 12.92 for sRGB)
067         * @param d &ge; 0 the offset d of the non-linear section (e.g., s = 0.055 for sRGB)
068         */
069        public ModifiedGammaMapping(double gamma, double a0, double s, double d) {
070                this.a0 = a0;
071                this.b0 = s * a0;
072                this.gamma = gamma;
073                this.igamma = 1.0 / gamma;
074                this.s = s;
075                this.d = d;
076        }
077
078        /**
079         * Function s(gamma, a0) derives the slope s of the linear section
080         * from parameters gamma and a0 (see Eq. 3.35 in [1]).
081         * 
082         * @param gamma the nominal gamma value for the forward mapping
083         * @param a0 the linear to non-linear transition point
084         * @return the slope s of the linear section
085         */
086        protected static double s(double gamma, double a0) {
087                return gamma / (a0 * (gamma - 1) + Math.pow(a0, 1 - gamma));
088        }
089        
090        /**
091         * Function d(gamma, a0) derives the offset d of the non-linear section
092         * from parameters gamma and a0 (see Eq. 3.35 in [1]).
093         *  
094         * @param gamma the nominal gamma value for the forward mapping
095         * @param a0 the linear to non-linear transition point
096         * @return the offset d of the non-linear section
097         */
098        protected static double d(double gamma, double a0) {
099                return 1.0 / (Math.pow(a0, gamma) * (gamma - 1) + 1) - 1;
100        }
101        
102    @Override
103        public double applyFwd(double a) {
104                return (a <= a0) ?
105                        s * a :
106                        (1 + d) * Math.pow(a, gamma) - d;
107    }
108    
109    @Override
110        public double applyInv(double b) {
111        return (b <= b0) ?
112                (b / s) :
113                        Math.pow((b + d) / (1 + d), igamma);
114    }
115    
116    @Override
117        public float applyFwd(float a) {
118                return (float) applyFwd((double) a);
119    }
120    
121    @Override
122        public float applyInv(float b) {
123        return (float) applyInv((double) b);
124    }
125    
126    // -----------------------------------------------
127    
128    /**
129         * Forward Gamma mapping (from linear to non-linear component values).
130         * 
131         * @param A an array of linear component values in [0,1]
132         * @return an array of gamma-corrected (non-linear) component values
133         */
134    public float[] applyFwd(float A[]) {
135        float[] B = new float[A.length];
136        for (int i = 0; i < A.length; i++) {
137                B[i] = applyFwd(A[i]);
138        }
139                return B;
140    }
141    
142    /**
143         * Inverse Gamma mapping (from non-linear to linear component values).
144         * 
145         * @param B an array of non-linear (Gamma-corrected) component value in [0,1]
146         * @return an array of linear component values
147         */
148    public float[] applyInv(float B[]) {
149        float[] A = new float[B.length];
150        for (int i = 0; i < B.length; i++) {
151                A[i] = applyInv(B[i]);
152        }
153                return A;
154    }
155
156}
